item.title: variable scope issues in Jinja2
item.description:
I tried to calculate the sum of a sequence in a loop in jinja2 template but got some trouble. Below is my initial code:

 1 from jinja2 import Template
 2 text1 = """
 3 {%- set sum = 100 -%}
 4 <ul>
 5 {%- for i in range(2) -%}
 6 {%- set sum = sum + 1 %}
 7 <li>{{sum}}</li>
 8 {%- endfor %}
 9 </ul>
10 {{sum}}
11 """
12 template = Template(text1)
13 print template.render()

Here’s the output:

1 <ul>
2 <li>101</li>
3 <li>102</li>
4 </ul>
5 100

At the end of the loop, sum is 100, not the expected 103. I was confused at first. By doing some search, I found this may be the issue caused by variable scope. Then I tried to work around.

 1 from jinja2 import Template
 2 text2 = """
 3 {%- set l = [0] -%}
 4 <ul>
 5 {%- for i in range(2) -%}
 6 {%- if l[0] = l[0] + 1 %}
 7 {%- endif -%}
 8 <li>{{l[0]}}</li>
 9 {%- endfor %}
10 </ul>
11 {{l[0]}}
12 """
13 template = Template(text2)
14 print template.render()

Unfortunately assignment is a statement instead of an expresion in Python, unlike the assignment expression in C++. So we can’t use it in if and got the following error:

 1 Traceback (most recent call last):
 2   File "test.py", line 26, in <module>
 3     template = Template(text2)
 4   File "C:\Python27\lib\site-packages\jinja2\environment.py", line 906, in __new__
 5     return env.from_string(source, template_class=cls)
 6   File "C:\Python27\lib\site-packages\jinja2\environment.py", line 841, in from_string
 7     return cls.from_code(self, self.compile(source), globals, None)
 8   File "C:\Python27\lib\site-packages\jinja2\environment.py", line 554, in compile
 9     self.handle_exception(exc_info, source_hint=source)
10   File "C:\Python27\lib\site-packages\jinja2\environment.py", line 742, in handle_exception
11     reraise(exc_type, exc_value, tb)
12   File "<unknown>", line 5, in template
13 jinja2.exceptions.TemplateSyntaxError: expected token 'end of statement block', got '='

We need to find a function to set list’s element instead of the assignment expression. Fortunately we’ve lots of methods for that. 

 1 from jinja2 import Template
 2 text2 = """
 3 <ul>
 4 {%-set l = [100] %}
 5 {%- for i in range(2) %}
 6 {%- if l.insert(0, l[0] + i) -%}
 7 {% endif %}
 8 <li>{{l[0]}}</li>
 9 {%- endfor %}
10 </ul>
11 {{l[0]}}
12 """
13 template = Template(text2)
14 print template.render()

Now we got what we expected.

1 <ul>
2 <li>100</li>
3 <li>101</li>
4 </ul>
5 101

We can use dummy variable and set to replace if statement and save one line.

 1 from jinja2 import Template
 2 text2 = """
 3 <ul>
 4 {%-set l = [100] %}
 5 {%- for i in range(2) %}
 6 {%- set _ = l.insert(0, l[0] + i) %}
 7 <li>{{l[0]}}</li>
 8 {%- endfor %}
 9 </ul>
10 {{l[0]}}
11 """
12 template = Template(text2)
13 print template.render()

Reference:

Can a Jinja variable’s scope extend beyond in an inner block?

item.title: read write lock
item.description:
Read write lock is widely used in concurrent environments. It enables multiple reader to read resource concurrently but only one writer can write to it without any read action at the same time. The concept is easy to understand, but to implement a well behaved read write lock is not so easy.

Implement 1: two mutex for read and write, one reader count

 1 class RWLock
 2 {
 3 private:
 4     mutex rlock_;
 5     mutex wlock_;
 6     int readers_ = 0;
 7 public:
 8     void LockWrite() {
 9         wlock_.lock();
10     }
11 
12     void UnlockWrite() {
13         wlock_.unlock();
14     }
15 
16     void LockRead() {
17         lock_guard<mutex> guard(rlock_);
18         if (readers_++ == 0) {
19             LockWrite();
20         }
21     }
22 
23     void UnlockRead() {
24         lock_guard<mutex> guard(rlock_);
25         if (--readers_ == 0) {
26             // unlock reader thread may be different from the thread who locked the writer
27             UnlockWrite();
28         }
29     }
30 };

There’s a big drawback in the implementation that the last reader thread who call unlock writers may be different from the first thread who lock writers. It will cause undefine behavor.

  • std::mutex::unlock:

    If the mutex is not currently locked by the calling thread, it causes undefined behavior.

  • ReleaseMutex:

    The ReleaseMutex function fails if the calling thread does not own the mutex object.

  • pthread_mutex_unlock

    If a thread attempts to unlock a mutex that it has not locked or a mutex that is unlocked, undefined behavior results.

To fix the underfined behavior issue, we can use condition variable to notify between the reader and writer processes.

 1 class RWLockCV{
 2     mutex lock_;
 3     condition_variable cv_;
 4     int writers_ = 0;
 5     int readers_ = 0;
 6 public:
 7     void LockWrite() {
 8         unique_lock<mutex> lock(lock_);
 9         while (readers_ > 0 || writers_ > 0) cv_.wait(lock);
10         ++writers_;
11     }
12 
13     void UnlockWrite() {
14         unique_lock<mutex> lock(lock_);
15         --writers_;
16         cv_.notify_all();
17     }
18 
19     void LockRead() {
20         unique_lock<mutex> lock(lock_);
21         while (writers_ > 0) cv_.wait(lock);
22         ++readers_;
23     }
24 
25     void UnlockRead() {
26         unique_lock<mutex> lock(lock_);
27         if (--readers_ == 0) cv_.notify_all();
28     }
29 };

In the above code every lock and unlock pair are in a function’s scope and no lock is unlocked in another process/thread. How does it work? Let’s study several cases.

  1. Two writer process. 
    1 // process 1 at time t1
2 writer1.LockWrite();
3 // process 2 at time t2
4 Writer2.LockWrite();
5 // process 1 at time t3
6 writer1.UnlockWrite();
    At time t1, readers and writers are 0, writer1 set writers_ to 1. At time t2, writer2 see writers_ > 0, unlock and wait on cv At time t3, writer1 set writers_ to 0, and notify all processes waiting on cv, then release the lock. Writer2 is notified, then tried to acquire the lock and acquired the lock while writer1 released it.
  2. One writer and one reader. Writer first acquired the lock. 
    1 // process 1 at time t1
2 writer1.LockWrite();
3 // process 2 at time t2
4 reader1.LockRead();
5 // process 1 at time t3
6 writer1.UnlockWrite();
    Similar analysis as above. Just replace writer2 with reader1.
  3. One writer and two readers 
    1 // process 1 at time t1
2 writer1.LockWrite();
3 // process 2 at time t2
4 reader1.LockRead();
5 // process 3 at time t3
6 reader2.LockWrite();
7 // process 1 at time t4
8 writer1.UnlockWrite();
    At t4 when writer1 set writers to 0 and notify all, both reader1 and reader2 will wake up and try to acquire the lock. After writer1 released the lock, if reader2 acquired the lock, it will then set readers_ to 1 and release the lock, began reading. Then reader 1 will acquire the lock, set readers_ to 2, released the lock and began read. From this case we see the importance of notify_all. If we use notify_one in UnlockWriter, only one reader will be token up, another will still hang on the cv.
  4. One reader and two writers. 
    1 // process 1 at time t1
2 reader.LockRead();
3 // process 2 at time t2
4 writer1.LockWrite();
5 // process 3 at time t3
6 writer2.LockWrite();
7 // process 1 at time t4
8 reader1.UnlockWrite();
    At t4, when reader1 set readers_ to 0 and call cv_.notify_all, both writer1 and writer2 will wake up and try to acquire lock. After reader1 released the lock, if writer2 acquired the lock, increment writers_ to 1 and release the lock, writer1 then acquired the lock, but since writers_ is now 1, it can do nothing but wait again. It's a waste if we have many writers waiting on the cv. Only one can get the chance to execute, all others are woken up and soon sleep again. To solve the issue, we should use two cv: one for reader and call notify_all on that when unlock, another for writer and call notify_one when unlock.
  5. Multiple readers starve writer. 
     1 // process 1 at time t1
 2 reader.LockRead();
 3 // process 2 at time t2
 4 writer1.LockWrite();
 5 // process 3 at time t3
 6 reader2.LockRead();
 7 // process 1 at time t4
 8 reader1.UnlockWrite();
 9 // process 4 at time t5
10 reader3.LockRead();
11 // process 3 at time t6
12 reader2.UnlockWrite();
    At t3, when reader2 tried to lock, it got the lock and set readers_ to 2. At t4, after reader1 unlocked, writer1 was woken up but since readers_ is 1 now, it had to wait again. At t6 when reader2 released the lock, there was a reader 3 and writer1 had to wait again. So if there always came a reader before the last reader called UnlockReader, writer1 would never get a chance to execute. This issue is even harder to solve. We need a queue to recors each read/write request time and make those request served in the order they come as possible as we can. In some cases we can't gurante that if a reader comes while the buffer is empty.

item.title: double pointer
item.description:
Double pointer is a great tool to simplify certain programming tasks.

Let’s look into a simple example: merge two sorted linked list by spicing together the nodes of the orignal lists without creating new nodes.

Below is the define of linked node:

1 struct ListNode {
2     int val;
3     ListNode *next;
4     ListNode(int x) : val(x), next(NULL) {}
5 };

The simplest way is use a pointer h to record the head of merged list, and use another pointer p to record the tail of merged results;

 1 ListNode *mergeTwoLists(ListNode *l1, ListNode *l2) {
 2     ListNode* h = NULL, *p = NULL;
 3     while (l1 && l2) {
 4         if (l1->val <= l2->val) {
 5             if (!h) {
 6                 h = p = l1;
 7             }
 8             else {
 9                 p->next = l1;
10                 p = l1;
11             }
12             l1 = l1->next;
13         }
14         else {
15             if (!h) {
16                 h = p = l2;
17             }
18             else {
19                 p->next = l2;
20                 p = l2;
21             }
22             l2 = l2->next;
23         }
24     }
25     if (!h) h = l1 ? l1 : l2;
26     else p->next = l1 ? l1 : l2;
27     return h;
28 }

hmm, too many nested if else in the 28 line solution. How to elimate the detect of NULL of head? One trick is to use a dummy node.

 1 ListNode *mergeTwoLists(ListNode *l1, ListNode *l2) {
 2     ListNode dummy(-1), *p = &dummy;
 3     for (; l1 != nullptr && l2 != nullptr; p = p->next) {
 4         if (l1->val > l2->val) {
 5             p->next = l2;
 6             l2 = l2->next;
 7         }
 8         else { 
 9             p->next = l1;
10             l1 = l1->next;
11         }
12     }
13     p->next = l1 != nullptr ? l1 : l2;
14     return dummy.next;
15 }

Here we got a 15 line solution, 13 lines are elimated. Here a dummy node elemated the check of NULL for head and prev pointer. But how can we elimate the construct of a new dummy load if the cost is heavy? Double pointer may help.

 1 ListNode *mergeTwoLists(ListNode *l1, ListNode *l2) {
 2     ListNode* h = NULL, **p = &h;
 3     for (;l1&&l2;p=&((*p)->next)) {
 4         if (l1->val <= l2->val) {
 5             *p = l1;
 6             l1 = l1->next;
 7         }
 8         else {
 9             *p = l2;
10             l2 = l2->next;
11         }
12     }
13     *p = l1 ? l1 : l2;
14     return h;
15 }

Here’re some quizzes you can try with double pointer.

  • Remove Nth Node From End of List
  • Insertion Sort List
  • Reverse Linked List II
  • Partition List
  • Merge Two Sorted Lists

item.title: semaphore
item.description:
From wikipedia, a semaphore is a variable or abstract data type that is used for controlling access, by multiple processes, to a common resource in a parallel programming or a multi user environment.

A useful way to think of a semaphore is as a record of how many units of a particular resource are available, coupled with operations to safely. Below is pseudo code for semaphore define.

1 struct sem {
2     int count; // maximum count of processes that can access the sem at the same time
3     queue q; // waiting queues of processes on the semaphore.
4 };

There’re 3 operations on semaphore

 1 // init sem's count to n
 2 sem_init(sem, n);
 3 
 4 // if sem's count is > 0, decrease sem's count by 1 and continue
 5 // othewise, block and add the current thread to sem's waiting queue.
 6 wait(sem);
 7 
 8 // increase sem's count by 1
 9 // if there're processes in the waiting queue, pick up one and wake it up Y
10 signal(sem);

A general scenario for semaphore is the producer consumer problem. You have a buffer with N unit and lots of producer and consumer processes. You need to make sure that producer won’t add data into buffer if it’s full and consumer won’t try to remove data if the buffer is empty.

A typical solution for producer-consumer problem with semaphore is given below:

 1 const int BUFFER_SIZE = 5;
 2 queue q;
 3 semaphore emptySem, fullSem, mutexSem;
 4 init_sem(emptySem, BUFFER_SIZE);
 5 init_sem(fullSem, 0);
 6 init_sem(mutexSem, 1);
 7 init_queue(q, BUFFER_SIZE);
 8 
 9 void pruducer() {
10     wait(emptySem);
11     wait(mutexSem);
12     produce(q);
13     signal(mutexSem);
14     signal(fullSem);
15 }
16 
17 void consumer() {
18     wait(fullSem);
19     wait(mutexSem);
20     consume(q);
21     signal(mutexSem);
22     signal(fullSem)
23 }

Line 1~7 initialized 3 semaphores and a queue. At first we’ve 5 empty slots and 0 full slot, so set empty sem counter to 5 and full sem to 0. mutexSem just acted like a mutex and was set to 1.

Producer waits for empty sem at line 10. If we remove this line, more than current empty buffer’s count’s producers will call produce sequentially. If produce subroutine doesn’t perform boundary check, there’ll be a disaster. Even if produce subroutine performs boundary check and return without add extra element to queue, it still has chance to starve consumer process. Suppose we have a consumer that is waiting on mutexSem to consume the queue, in the worst case after first 5 producers that filled the buffer, the subsequent producer will 1 by 1 hold the mutexSem with nothing to do and the consumer is waiting for ever. So we must have a mechanism to block the producer while the queue is full. This is what line 10 is for.

Without line 11, multiple producer will access the queue concurrently and it’s a disaster.

item.title: Catalan number
item.description:
How many ways are there to push and pop n elements into and out a stack? We marked E as push and L as pop, the question can be converted to: how many ways to represent a 2n length string with E and L that in any of its prefixes, numbers of E are no less than numbers of L. If a 2n string composed by E and L can represent a way to push and pop n elements, we call it a good string.

From a 2n string with n E and n L, find first L before which it there’re same Es and Ls. If we can find such an L, the string doesn’t satisfy conditions above. We named such strings as bad string.

For a bad string, if we flip it after the first L before which there’re same Es and Ls, we got another 2n string composed by n+1 L and n-1 E.

For 2 different bad strings B1 and B2 with different flip position, the flipped strings of them shouldn’t be same. Assume B1’s flip position is p1, B2’s flip position is p2 and p1 < p2(index based 0, and p1 must > 0), then the lenght p1 prefix of blipped strings B1’ and B2’ are keeping unflipped and should be same with the original string. If the original strings have a same length p1 prefix, they should both flip at p1 position. So the prefix with a length p1 of B1 and B2 are different.

For 2 different bad strings B1 and B2 with same flip position p, there must be some different before or after p. No matter where the difference is, the difference part will be clipped or not samely for the two strings. So they keep different afte flip.

So different bad strings got different flipped strings with n+1 L and n-1 E.

Vice visa, for any two different strings that both have n+1 L and n-1 E, we flipped back after the first L that before which there’re same Es and Ls and get a string with same Es and Ls. Since there’re more Ls than Es, we can always find such an L. We can prove similarily that different original strings will get different flipped strings.

So there’s a 1-1 mapping from bad strings with n Es and n Ls to strings with n+1 L and n-1 E. So there’re C(2n, n-1) bad strings. The good string number is: C(2n, n) - C(2n, n-1) = C(2n, n) / (n+1). This is the famous Catalan number.

Cat(n) = C(2n, n)/(n+1).

Let’s try to get Cat(n) in another way: suppose before we popped k elements out before popping the first element out, for k = 0..n-1, we have

Cat(n) = sum(Cat(k)Cat(n-1-k)) (k=0…n-1)

Example 1: Ways to generate valid parenthesis sequences. Consider left parenthesis as push and right parenthesis as pop.

Example 2: Add parenthesis to expression of N matrix multiply. P(1) = 1, P(2) = P(1) * P(1), P(3) = P(1) * P(2) + P(2) * p(1), P(n) = Cat(n-1)

Example 3: How many different shapes of a n nodes binary tree. T(0) = 1, T(1) = 1, T(2) = T(0) * T(1) + T(1) * T(0) (left from 0 to n-1, right from n-1 to 0), T(n) = Cat(n)

Example 4: 2n points on a circle, how many ways to conect those points to n segments without crossing each other. F(0) = 1, F(1) = 1, F(2) = F(0) * F(1) + F(1) * F(0), F(n) = F(0)* F(n-1) + F(1) * F(n-2) + … F(n-1) * F(0) = Cat(n) (Select a base point, connect it with a segment to the point that has even points between them, So in the two sides of the segment there’re 2k points and 2n - 2 - 2k points…)

Example 5: Divide a convex polygon to triangles. T(2) = 1, T(3) = T(2)*T(2)=1, T(4) = T(2) * T(3) + T(3) * T(2)= 1, T(5) = T(2) * T(4) + T(3) * T(3) + T(4) * T(2) = Cat(n-2) (Select one side AB, select C from the other n-2 points to get a triangle, so there’s a pologon of k points on the side of AC, k = 2 to n-1, on the side BC, there’s a pologon of n+1-k points(C is the common points of two polygons), T(n)=sum(T(2)T(n-1)+…+T(n-1)T(2))

item.title: make a shared_ptr from scratch
item.description:
shared_ptr is a smart pointer since c++ 11 that will release you from managing the life cycle of objects shared among lots of components without an explicit owner. You can learn it from cplusplus.com. For more details and practice, boost is a great resource.

Let’s consider an interesting question: how to build a shared_ptr from the scratch.

Reference counter

  • You must have some mechanism to manage the reference count.
  • The reference count operation should be thread safe.
  • The reference count instance should be shared between several copies of shared_ptr, so it should be aggregated as a pointer, not composed in a shared_ptr.
  • Reference count object should destroy the object if needed. This makes the code of shared_ptr simple.

Here comes the reference count class:

 1 // thread safe inc
 2 inline long atomic_inc(long volatile* addend) {
 3     return InterlockedIncrement(addend);
 4 }
 5 
 6 // thread safe dec
 7 inline long atomic_dec(long volatile* addend) {
 8     return InterlockedDecrement(addend);
 9 }
10 
11 // Base class of ref count, handle all the logic of ref count
12 class RefCountBase {
13     long ref_count_ = 1;
14 public:
15 
16     RefCountBase(){
17     }
18 
19     RefCountBase(const RefCountBase&) = delete;
20 
21     RefCountBase& operator=(const RefCountBase&) = delete;
22 
23     virtual ~RefCountBase(){
24     }
25 
26     void Incref() {
27         atomic_inc(&ref_count_);
28     }
29 
30     void Decref() {
31         if (atomic_dec(&ref_count_) == 0) {
32             Destroy();
33             // when refcount == 0. delete the object itself
34             // so the owner needn't worry about when to releasing it
35             DeleteThis();
36         }
37     }
38 
39     long UseCount() const {
40         return ref_count_;
41     }
42 
43     // destroy the resource
44     virtual void Destroy() = 0;
45 
46     // destroy the object by itselfs
47     virtual void DeleteThis() = 0;
48 };
49 
50 // RefCount for pointer delete, use delete operator
51 // the most common ref count
52 template <class T>
53 class RefCount : public RefCountBase {
54     T* ptr_;
55 public:
56     RefCount(T* ptr) :ptr_(ptr) {
57 
58     }
59 
60     RefCount(const RefCount&) = delete;
61 
62     RefCount& operator=(RefCount&) = delete;
63 
64     virtual ~RefCount(){}
65 
66     virtual void Destroy() {
67         delete ptr_;
68         ptr_ = nullptr;
69     }
70 
71     virtual void DeleteThis() {
72         delete this;
73     }
74 };

Here we left Destroy and DeleteThis as pure virtual function in RefCountBase and implement it in RefCount. Because share_ptr can not only hold a object allocated by new, but also other resource that need a special destructor. Here’s the shared_ptr class.

  1 // shared_ptr
  2 // shared_ptr<string> p(new string("abc"));
  3 // shared_ptr<string> p2(p);
  4 template <class T>
  5 class shared_ptr {
  6 private:
  7     RefCountBase* pref_;
  8     T* ptr_;
  9 public:
 10     shared_ptr(): pref_(nullptr), ptr_(nullptr) {
 11     }
 12 
 13     shared_ptr(nullptr_t) :pref_(nullptr), ptr_(nullptr) {
 14     }
 15 
 16     template<class U> explicit shared_ptr(U* ptr): pref_(new RefCount<T>(ptr)), ptr_(ptr) {
 17     }
 18 
 19     
 20     shared_ptr(const shared_ptr& rhs) {
 21         reset(rhs.ptr_, rhs.pref_);
 22     }
 23     
 24     template<class U> shared_ptr(const shared_ptr<U>& rhs) {
 25         reset(rhs.ptr_, rhs.pref_);
 26     }
 27     
 28     shared_ptr(shared_ptr&& rhs): pref_(rhs.pref_), ptr_(rhs.ptr_) {
 29         rhs.pref_ = nullptr;
 30         rhs.ptr_ = nullptr;
 31     }
 32     
 33     template <class U> shared_ptr(shared_ptr<U>&& rhs) : pref_(rhs.pref_), ptr_(rhs.ptr_) {
 34         rhs.pref_ = nullptr;
 35         rhs.ptr_ = nullptr;
 36     }
 37     
 38     shared_ptr& operator=(const shared_ptr& rhs) {
 39         reset(rhs.ptr_, rhs.pref_);
 40         return *this;
 41     }
 42     
 43     template<class U>
 44     shared_ptr& operator=(const shared_ptr<U>& rhs) {
 45         reset(rhs.ptr_, rhs.pref_);
 46         return *this;
 47     }
 48     
 49     shared_ptr& operator=(shared_ptr&& rhs) {
 50         std::swap(pref_, rhs.pref_);
 51         std::swap(ptr_, rhs.ptr_);
 52         return *this;
 53     }
 54     
 55     template <class U>
 56     shared_ptr& operator=(shared_ptr<U>&& rhs) {
 57         // can't swap internal fields directly
 58         // assigning from U to T is one way
 59         shared_ptr(std::move(rhs)).swap(*this);
 60         return *this;
 61     }
 62     
 63     ~shared_ptr() {
 64         Decref();
 65     }
 66     
 67     void reset() {
 68         reset(nullptr, nullptr);
 69     }
 70     
 71     T& operator*() const {
 72         return *(get());
 73     }
 74     
 75     T* get() const {
 76         return ptr_;
 77     }
 78     
 79     T* operator->() const {
 80         return get();
 81     }
 82     
 83     void swap(shared_ptr& x) {
 84         std::swap(ptr_, x.ptr_);
 85         std::swap(pref_, x.pref_);
 86     }
 87     
 88     long use_count() const {
 89         if (!pref_) {
 90             return 0;
 91         }
 92         return pref_->UseCount();
 93     }
 94 
 95     bool unique() const {
 96         return use_count() == 1;
 97     }
 98 
 99     explicit operator bool() const {
100         return get() != nullptr;
101     }
102 
103     template <class U> bool owner_before(shared_ptr<U>& rhs) {
104         return ptr_ < rhs.ptr_;
105     }
106 private:
107     void reset(T* ptr, RefCountBase* refCount) {
108         if (pref_) {
109             pref_->Decref();
110         }
111         ptr_ = ptr;
112         pref_ = refCount;
113         if (refCount) {
114             refCount->Incref();
115         }
116     }
117     
118     void Decref() {
119         if (pref_) {
120             pref_->Decref();
121             pref_ = nullptr;
122         }
123     }
124 
125     template <class U>
126         friend class shared_ptr;
127 };

Customized deleter

To support customize deleter, we should add another class RefCountDel whose constructor accept a second argument deletor.

 1 // handle resources with deleter
 2 template <class T, class D>
 3 class RefCountDel: public RefCountBase {
 4 private:
 5     T* ptr_;
 6     D del_;
 7 public:
 8     RefCountDel(T* ptr, D del) : ptr_(ptr), del_(del) {}
 9 
10     RefCountDel(const RefCountDel&) = delete;
11 
12     RefCountDel& operator=(const RefCountDel&) = delete;
13 
14     virtual void DeleteThis() {
15         delete this;
16     }
17 
18     virtual void Destroy() {
19         del_(ptr_);
20     }
21 };
22 
23 template <class T> shared_ptr {
24     // ...
25     template<class U, class D> shared_ptr(U* ptr, D del) : pref_(new RefCountDel<U, D>(ptr, del)), ptr_(ptr) {
26     }
27 
28     template<class D> shared_ptr(nullptr_t, D del) : pref_(new RefCountDel<T, D>(nullptr, del)), ptr_(nullptr) {
29     }
30     // ...
31 };

Array support

shared_ptr in C++ 11 doesn’t support array. We can extend our shared_ptr to support it. To support array, we should create shared_ptr with a customized deleter, like this:

1 shared_ptr<int> p(new int[10], std::default_delete<int[]>());

But the above code looks a bit ugly. Since new array is used widely, we should try to elimate the second deleter argument.

To fix it, we have following ways:

  1. Create a specialization copy of sahred_ptr for array. This would work, but will introduce redundant codes.
  2. Don’t create the RefCount class directly with new in shared_ptr. Instead create it with a template function that has a specialization copy for array.

Here is the solution.

 1 template <class T, class U>
 2 RefCountBase* CreateRefCount(shared_ptr<T>* /* for template parameter deduction */, U* p) {
 3     return new RefCount<T>(p);
 4 }
 5 
 6 template <class T>
 7 RefCountBase* CreateRefCount(shared_ptr<T[]>* /* for template parameter deduction */, T* p) {
 8     return new RefCountDel<T, std::default_delete<T[]>>(p, std::default_delete<T[]>());
 9 }
10 
11 template <class T>
12 struct sp_element
13 {
14     typedef T type;
15 };
16 
17 template <class T>
18 struct sp_element<T[]>
19 {
20     typedef T type;
21 };
22 
23 template <class T> shared_ptr {
24     // if we use T* here and T is array type like int[], we'll have trouble
25     typedef typename sp_element<T>::type element_type;
26     RefCountBase* pref_;
27     element_type* ptr_;
28 public
29     explicit shared_ptr(element_type* ptr) : ptr_(ptr) {
30         pref_ = CreateRefCount(this, ptr);
31     }
32 
33     template<class U> explicit shared_ptr(U* ptr): ptr_(ptr) {
34         pref_ = CreateRefCount(this, ptr);
35     }
36 private:
37     template<class U>
38     void reset(U* ptr, RefCountBase* refCount) {
39         if (pref_) {
40             pref_->Decref();
41         }
42         ptr_ = ptr;
43         pref_ = refCount;
44         if (refCount) {
45             refCount->Incref();
46         }
47     }
48     ...
49 }

Alias constructor

In shared_ptr we stored two pointers, one is the stored pointer ptr, one is the ref count pointer pref. Since pref_ has a copy of the stored pointer, why we store another copy in the shared_ptr object? This is for alias consturector. Think about a scenario: you have a big object a in type A allocated by new, and it has a small field b with type B. You want to keep a shared_ptr for b, how can you do this?

Since b is owned by a, you shouldn’t delete it by yourself with a shared_ptr. You can use it like:

1 shared_ptr<A> a(new A);
2 a.b->func(...)

But a.b->func(…) is not convenient as a->func(…). And you can’t keep a raw pointer to a.a without lifecycle managment. If a is destroyed, pointer to a.a will be dangling.

Here comes alias constructor

1 shared_ptr<A> a(new A);
2 shared_ptr<B> b(a, &a.b);
3 b->func(...)

For more details. please see shared_ptr aliasing constructor.

Below is the implement:

1 // aliasing
2 template <class U> shared_ptr(const shared_ptr<U>& rhs, element_type* ptr):ptr_(ptr) {
3     pref_ = rhs.pref_;
4     if (pref_) {
5         pref_->Incref();
6     }
7 }

make_shared

So far everything is OK, except that to allocate an object with an shared_ptr, we need to new, one for the object itself, and another is for the refCount. How can we use only one memory allocation to allocate the two object? One idea is to put the stored object as a field of ref count object. We can know the object size at compile time, but how can we initialize it in the runtime with the infinite possibilities of constructor? Fortunatelly c++ 11 brings us variadic template and perfect forwarding. So we can use (placement new)[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Placement_syntax] to initialize the stored object with arguments we don’t know in the templates.

 1 template <class T>
 2 class RefCountObj: public RefCountBase {
 3 private:
 4     typename std::aligned_storage<sizeof(T)>::type storage_;
 5 public:
 6     template<class... Types>
 7     RefCountObj(Types... args) {
 8         new (&storage_)T(std::forward<Types>(args)...);
 9     }
10 
11     T* Get() const {
12         return (T*)(&storage_);
13     }
14 
15     virtual void Destroy() {
16         Get()->~T();
17     }
18 
19     virtual void DeleteThis() {
20         delete this;
21     }
22 };
23 
24 template <class T, class... Types>
25 shared_ptr<T> make_shared(Types&&... args) {
26     RefCountObj<T>* obj = new RefCountObj<T>(std::forward<Types>(args)...);
27     shared_ptr<T> p;
28     p.reset_ref_0(obj->Get(), obj);
29     return p;
30 }

Code list

Here’s the full code list:

  1 #pragma once
  2 #ifdef _WIN32
  3 #include <windows.h>
  4 #endif
  5 #include <algorithm>
  6 #include <cstddef>
  7 #include <memory>
  8 
  9 namespace mp {
 10     template <class T> class shared_ptr;
 11     // thread safe inc
 12     inline long atomic_inc(long volatile* addend) {
 13         return InterlockedIncrement(addend);
 14     }
 15 
 16     // thread safe dec
 17     inline long atomic_dec(long volatile* addend) {
 18         return InterlockedDecrement(addend);
 19     }
 20 
 21     // Base class of ref count, handle all the logic of ref count
 22     class RefCountBase {
 23         long ref_count_ = 1;
 24     public:
 25         RefCountBase(){
 26         }
 27         RefCountBase(const RefCountBase&) = delete;
 28         RefCountBase& operator=(const RefCountBase&) = delete;
 29 
 30         virtual ~RefCountBase(){
 31         }
 32 
 33         void Incref() {
 34             atomic_inc(&ref_count_);
 35         }
 36         void Decref() {
 37             if (atomic_dec(&ref_count_) == 0) {
 38                 Destroy();
 39                 // when refcount == 0. delete the object itself
 40                 // so the owner needn't worry about when to releasing it
 41                 DeleteThis();
 42             }
 43         }
 44         long UseCount() const {
 45             return ref_count_;
 46         }
 47         // destroy the resource
 48         virtual void Destroy() = 0;
 49         // destroy the object by itselfs
 50         virtual void DeleteThis() = 0;
 51     };
 52 
 53     // RefCount for pointer delete, use delete operator
 54     // the most common ref count
 55     template <class T>
 56     class RefCount : public RefCountBase {
 57         T* ptr_;
 58     public:
 59         RefCount(T* ptr) :ptr_(ptr) {
 60 
 61         }
 62 
 63         RefCount(const RefCount&) = delete;
 64 
 65         RefCount& operator=(RefCount&) = delete;
 66 
 67         virtual ~RefCount(){}
 68 
 69         virtual void Destroy() {
 70             delete ptr_;
 71             ptr_ = nullptr;
 72         }
 73 
 74         virtual void DeleteThis() {
 75             delete this;
 76         }
 77     };
 78 
 79     template <class T, class D>
 80     class RefCountDel: public RefCountBase {
 81     private:
 82         T* ptr_;
 83         D del_;
 84     public:
 85         RefCountDel(T* ptr, D del): ptr_(ptr), del_(del) {
 86         }
 87 
 88         RefCountDel(const RefCountDel&) = delete;
 89 
 90         RefCountDel& operator=(const RefCountDel&) = delete;
 91 
 92         virtual void Destroy() {
 93             del_(ptr_);
 94         }
 95 
 96         virtual void DeleteThis() {
 97             delete this;
 98         }
 99     };
100 
101     template <class T>
102     class RefCountObj: public RefCountBase {
103     private:
104         typename std::aligned_storage<sizeof(T)>::type storage_;
105     public:
106         template<class... Types>
107         RefCountObj(Types... args) {
108             new (&storage_)T(std::forward<Types>(args)...);
109         }
110 
111         T* Get() const {
112             return (T*)(&storage_);
113         }
114 
115         virtual void Destroy() {
116             Get()->~T();
117         }
118 
119         virtual void DeleteThis() {
120             delete this;
121         }
122     };
123 
124     template <class T, class... Types>
125     shared_ptr<T> make_shared(Types&&... args) {
126         RefCountObj<T>* obj = new RefCountObj<T>(std::forward<Types>(args)...);
127         shared_ptr<T> p;
128         p.reset_ref_0(obj->Get(), obj);
129         return p;
130     }
131 
132     template <class T, class U>
133     RefCountBase* CreateRefCount(shared_ptr<T>* /* for template parameter deduction */, U* p) {
134         return new RefCount<T>(p);
135     }
136 
137     template <class T>
138     RefCountBase* CreateRefCount(shared_ptr<T[]>* /* for template parameter deduction */, T* p) {
139         return new RefCountDel<T, std::default_delete<T[]>>(p, std::default_delete<T[]>());
140     }
141 
142     template <class T>
143     struct sp_element
144     {
145         typedef T type;
146     };
147 
148     template <class T>
149     struct sp_element<T[]>
150     {
151         typedef T type;
152     };
153 
154     // shared_ptr
155     // shared_ptr<string> p(new string("abc"));
156     // shared_ptr<string> p2(p);
157     template <class T>
158     class shared_ptr {
159     private:
160         // if we use T* here and T is array type like int[], we'll have trouble
161         typedef typename sp_element<T>::type element_type;
162         RefCountBase* pref_;
163         element_type* ptr_;
164     public:
165         shared_ptr() : pref_(nullptr), ptr_(nullptr) {
166         }
167 
168         shared_ptr(element_type* ptr) : ptr_(ptr) {
169             pref_ = CreateRefCount(this, ptr);
170         }
171 
172         template<class U> explicit shared_ptr(U* ptr) :
173             pref_(CreateRefCount(this, ptr)), ptr_(ptr) {
174         }
175 
176         template<class U, class D> shared_ptr(U* ptr, D del) :
177             pref_(new RefCountDel<U, D>(ptr, del)), ptr_(ptr) {
178         }
179 
180         shared_ptr(nullptr_t) :pref_(nullptr), ptr_(nullptr) {
181         }
182 
183         template<class D> shared_ptr(nullptr_t, D del) : 
184             pref_(new RefCountDel<T, D>(nullptr, del)), ptr_(nullptr) {
185         }
186 
187         template<class U> shared_ptr(const shared_ptr<U>& u, T* ptr):
188             pref_(nullptr), ptr_(nullptr){
189             reset_ref(ptr, u.pref_);
190         }
191         
192         shared_ptr(const shared_ptr& rhs):
193             pref_(nullptr), ptr_(nullptr) {
194             reset_ref(rhs.ptr_, rhs.pref_);
195         }
196 
197         template<class U> shared_ptr(const shared_ptr<U>& rhs): 
198             ptr_(nullptr), pref_(nullptr) {
199             reset_ref(rhs.ptr_, rhs.pref_);
200         }
201 
202         // move ctor
203         shared_ptr(shared_ptr&& rhs): 
204             pref_(rhs.pref_), ptr_(rhs.ptr_) {
205             rhs.pref_ = nullptr;
206             rhs.ptr_ = nullptr;
207         }
208         template <class U> shared_ptr(shared_ptr<U>&& rhs) : pref_(rhs.pref_), ptr_(rhs.ptr_) {
209             rhs.pref_ = nullptr;
210             rhs.ptr_ = nullptr;
211         }
212         
213         shared_ptr& operator=(const shared_ptr& rhs) {
214             reset_ref(rhs.ptr_, rhs.pref_);
215             return *this;
216         }
217 
218         shared_ptr& operator=(shared_ptr&& rhs) {
219             reset_ref(rhs.ptr_, rhs.pref_);
220             return *this;
221         }
222 
223         template <class U>
224         shared_ptr& operator=(shared_ptr<U>&& rhs) {
225             reset_ref(rhs.ptr_, rhs.pref_);
226             return *this;
227         }
228 
229         ~shared_ptr() {
230             Decref();
231         }
232         void reset() {
233             reset_ref(nullptr, nullptr);
234         }
235 
236         template <class U>
237         void reset(U* ptr) {
238             shared_ptr<T>(ptr).swap(*this);
239         }
240 
241         template< class U, class D>
242         void reset(U* ptr, D del) {
243             shared_ptr<T>(ptr, del).swap(*this);
244         }
245 
246         T& operator*() const {
247             return *(get());
248         }
249         T* get() const {
250             return ptr_;
251         }
252         T* operator->() const {
253             return get();
254         }
255 
256         void swap(shared_ptr& x) {
257             std::swap(ptr_, x.ptr_);
258             std::swap(pref_, x.pref_);
259         }
260         long use_count() const {
261             if (!pref_) {
262                 return 0;
263             }
264             return pref_->UseCount();
265         }
266         bool unique() const {
267             return use_count() == 1;
268         }
269         explicit operator bool() const {
270             return get() != nullptr;
271         }
272         template <class U> bool owner_before(shared_ptr<U>& rhs) {
273             return pref_ < rhs.pref_;
274         }
275     private:
276         // reset without incref
277         void reset_ref_0(element_type* ptr, RefCountBase* refCount) {
278             if (pref_) {
279                 pref_->Decref();
280             }
281             ptr_ = ptr;
282             pref_ = refCount;
283 
284         }
285         void reset_ref(element_type* ptr, RefCountBase* refCount) {
286             if (refCount) {
287                 refCount->Incref();
288             }
289             reset_ref_0(ptr, refCount);
290         }
291         
292 
293         void Decref() {
294             if (pref_) {
295                 pref_->Decref();
296                 pref_ = nullptr;
297             }
298         }
299 
300         // friends
301         template <class U> friend class shared_ptr;
302         template <class U, class... Types> friend shared_ptr<U> make_shared(Types&&... args);
303     };
304 
305     template <class T>
306     void swap(shared_ptr<T>& lhs, shared_ptr<T>& rhs) {
307         lhs.swap(rhs);
308     }
309 
310     template < class T, class U > 
311     bool operator==(const shared_ptr<T>& lhs, const shared_ptr<U>& rhs) {
312         return lhs.get() == rhs.get();
313     }
314 
315     template< class T, class U > 
316     bool operator!=(const shared_ptr<T>& lhs, const shared_ptr<U>& rhs) {
317         return lhs.get() != rhs.get();
318     }
319 
320     template< class T, class U > 
321     bool operator<(const shared_ptr<T>& lhs, const shared_ptr<U>& rhs) {
322         return lhs.get() < rhs.get();
323     }
324     template< class T, class U > 
325     bool operator>(const shared_ptr<T>& lhs, const shared_ptr<U>& rhs) {
326         return lhs.get() > rhs.get();
327     }
328     template< class T, class U > 
329     bool operator<=(const shared_ptr<T>& lhs, const shared_ptr<U>& rhs) {
330         return lhs.get() <= rhs.get();
331     }
332 
333     template< class T, class U > 
334     bool operator>=(const shared_ptr<T>& lhs, const shared_ptr<U>& rhs) {
335         return lhs.get() >= rhs.get();
336     }
337 
338     template< class T > 
339     bool operator==(const shared_ptr<T>& lhs, std::nullptr_t) {
340         return lhs.get() == nullptr;
341     }
342 
343     template< class T >
344     bool operator==(std::nullptr_t, const shared_ptr<T>& rhs) {
345         return nullptr == rhs.get();
346     }
347 
348     template< class T >
349     bool operator!=(const shared_ptr<T>& lhs, std::nullptr_t) {
350         return lhs.get() != nullptr;
351     }
352 
353     template< class T >
354     bool operator!=(std::nullptr_t, const shared_ptr<T>& rhs) {
355         return nullptr != rhs.get();
356     }
357 
358     template< class T >
359     bool operator<(const shared_ptr<T>& lhs, std::nullptr_t) {
360         return lhs.get() < nullptr;
361     }
362 
363     template< class T >
364     bool operator<(std::nullptr_t, const shared_ptr<T>& rhs) {
365         return nullptr < rhs.get();
366     }
367 
368     template< class T >
369     bool operator<=(const shared_ptr<T>& lhs, std::nullptr_t) {
370         return lhs.get() <= nullptr;
371     }
372 
373     template< class T >
374     bool operator<=(std::nullptr_t, const shared_ptr<T>& rhs) {
375         return nullptr <= rhs.get();
376     }
377 
378     template< class T >
379     bool operator>(const shared_ptr<T>& lhs, std::nullptr_t) {
380         return lhs.get() > nullptr;
381     }
382 
383     template< class T >
384     bool operator>(std::nullptr_t, const shared_ptr<T>& rhs) {
385         return nullptr > rhs.get();
386     }
387 
388     template< class T >
389     bool operator>=(const shared_ptr<T>& lhs, std::nullptr_t) {
390         return lhs.get() >= nullptr;
391     }
392 
393     template< class T >
394     bool operator>=(std::nullptr_t, const shared_ptr<T>& rhs) {
395         return nullptr >= rhs.get();
396     }
397 }

Here’s the test code.

  1 #include "stdafx.h"
  2 #include "smartptr.h"
  3 
  4 namespace {
  5     using namespace mp;
  6     class B {
  7     public:
  8         int value_ = 0;
  9         int Inc() {
 10             return ++value_;
 11         }
 12     };
 13 
 14     class A
 15     {
 16     public:
 17         static std::string ctor_dtor_recorder_;
 18         void ClearCtorDtorRecorder() {
 19             A::ctor_dtor_recorder_.clear();
 20         }
 21         int value_;
 22         B b_;
 23         A() {
 24             value_ = 0;
 25             ctor_dtor_recorder_.push_back('C');
 26         }
 27         
 28         A(int val) : value_(val) {
 29             ctor_dtor_recorder_.push_back('C');
 30         }
 31 
 32         int Inc() {
 33             return ++value_;
 34         }
 35         ~A() {
 36             ctor_dtor_recorder_.push_back('D');
 37         }
 38     };
 39 
 40     std::string A::ctor_dtor_recorder_;
 41 
 42     class A2: public A {
 43     };
 44 
 45     class SharedPtrTest: public testing::Test {
 46         protected:
 47             virtual void SetUp() {
 48                 A::ctor_dtor_recorder_.clear();
 49             }
 50     };
 51 
 52     #define AssertCtorDtor(expected) ASSERT_EQ((expected), A::ctor_dtor_recorder_)
 53     
 54     TEST_F(SharedPtrTest, ctor) {
 55         A::ctor_dtor_recorder_.clear();
 56         {
 57             A* a = new A();
 58             shared_ptr<A> p(a);
 59         }
 60         AssertCtorDtor("CD");
 61     }
 62 
 63     TEST_F(SharedPtrTest, ctor_array_deleter) {
 64         int i = 0;
 65         auto x = [&i](A* a1) {++i; delete[] a1; };
 66         mp::shared_ptr<A[]> a(new A[5], x);
 67         AssertCtorDtor("CCCCC");
 68         a.reset();
 69         AssertCtorDtor("CCCCCDDDDD");
 70     }
 71 
 72     TEST_F(SharedPtrTest, ctor_array) {
 73         mp::shared_ptr<A[]> a(new A[5]);
 74         AssertCtorDtor("CCCCC");
 75         a.reset();
 76         AssertCtorDtor("CCCCCDDDDD");
 77     }
 78 
 79     TEST_F(SharedPtrTest, nullptr) {
 80         shared_ptr<A> p(nullptr);
 81         ASSERT_EQ(nullptr, p.get());
 82     }
 83 
 84     TEST_F(SharedPtrTest, nullptr_deleter) {
 85         int i = 0;
 86         auto x = [&i](A* p1){++i; delete p1; };
 87         {
 88             shared_ptr<A> p(nullptr, x);
 89             ASSERT_EQ(nullptr, p.get());
 90         }
 91         ASSERT_EQ(1, i);
 92         AssertCtorDtor("");
 93     }
 94 
 95     TEST_F(SharedPtrTest, ctor_aliasing) {
 96         auto pa = new A();
 97         shared_ptr<A> a(pa);
 98         shared_ptr<B> b(a, &a->b_);
 99         ASSERT_EQ(2, b.use_count());
100         a.reset();
101         AssertCtorDtor("C");
102         b->Inc();
103         ASSERT_EQ(1, pa->b_.value_);
104         b.reset();
105         AssertCtorDtor("CD");
106     }
107 
108     TEST_F(SharedPtrTest, copy_ctor) {
109         {
110             A* a = new A();
111             shared_ptr<A> p(a);
112             shared_ptr<A> p2(p);
113             p2->Inc();
114             ASSERT_EQ(1, a->value_);
115         }
116         AssertCtorDtor("CD");
117     }
118 
119     TEST_F(SharedPtrTest, ctor_deletor) {
120         int i = 0;
121         auto x = [&i](A* p) {++i; delete p; };
122         {
123             shared_ptr<A> p(new A(), x);
124         }
125         AssertCtorDtor("CD");
126         ASSERT_EQ(1, i);
127     }
128 
129     TEST_F(SharedPtrTest, ctor_difftype) {
130         {
131             A2* a = new A2();
132             shared_ptr<A> p(a);
133         }
134         AssertCtorDtor("CD");
135     }
136 
137     TEST_F(SharedPtrTest, copy_ctor_difftype) {
138         {
139             A2* a = new A2();
140             shared_ptr<A2> p(a);
141             shared_ptr<A> p2(p);
142             p2->Inc();
143             ASSERT_EQ(1, a->value_);
144         }
145         AssertCtorDtor("CD");
146     }
147 
148     TEST_F(SharedPtrTest, move_ctor) {
149         A* a = new A();
150         shared_ptr<A> p1(a);
151         shared_ptr<A> p2(std::move(p1));
152         ASSERT_EQ(nullptr, p1.get());
153         ASSERT_TRUE(p2.unique());
154     }
155 
156     TEST_F(SharedPtrTest, move_ctor_difftype) {
157         A2* a = new A2();
158         shared_ptr<A2> p1(a);
159         shared_ptr<A> p2(std::move(p1));
160         ASSERT_EQ(nullptr, p1.get());
161         ASSERT_EQ(a, p2.get());
162     }
163 
164     TEST_F(SharedPtrTest, assign_op) {
165         shared_ptr<A> p0;
166         {
167             A* a = new A();
168             shared_ptr<A> p(a);
169             p0 = p;
170         }
171         AssertCtorDtor("C");
172     }
173 
174     TEST_F(SharedPtrTest, reset) {
175         shared_ptr<A> p(new A());
176         AssertCtorDtor("C");
177         p.reset();
178         AssertCtorDtor("CD");
179     }
180 
181     TEST_F(SharedPtrTest, reset_difftype) {
182         shared_ptr<A> p(new A());
183         AssertCtorDtor("C");
184         p.reset(new A2());
185         AssertCtorDtor("CCD");
186     }
187 
188     TEST_F(SharedPtrTest, reset_difftype_deletor) {
189         shared_ptr<A> p(new A());
190         AssertCtorDtor("C");
191         int i = 0;
192         auto x = [&i](A* p1) {++i; delete p1; };
193         p.reset(new A2(), x);
194         AssertCtorDtor("CCD");
195         p.reset();
196         AssertCtorDtor("CCDD");
197     }
198 
199     TEST_F(SharedPtrTest, get) {
200         A* a = new A();
201         shared_ptr<A> p(a);
202         ASSERT_EQ(a, p.get());
203         p.reset();
204         ASSERT_EQ(nullptr, p.get());
205     }
206 
207     TEST_F(SharedPtrTest, arrow) {
208         A* a = new A();
209         shared_ptr<A> p(a);
210         p->Inc();
211         ASSERT_EQ(1, a->value_);
212     }
213 
214     TEST_F(SharedPtrTest, deference) {
215         A* a = new A();
216         shared_ptr<A> p(a);
217         (*p).Inc();
218         ASSERT_EQ(1, a->value_);
219     }
220 
221     TEST_F(SharedPtrTest, swap) {
222         A* a1 = new A();
223         A* a2 = new A();
224         shared_ptr<A> p1(a1), p11(p1);
225         shared_ptr<A> p2(a2);
226         p1.swap(p2);
227         ASSERT_EQ(a2, p1.get());
228         ASSERT_EQ(a1, p2.get());
229         ASSERT_EQ(a1, p11.get());
230     }
231 
232     TEST_F(SharedPtrTest, use_count) {
233         shared_ptr<A> p1(new A());
234         ASSERT_EQ(1, p1.use_count());
235         shared_ptr<A> p2;
236         ASSERT_EQ(0, p2.use_count());
237         p2 = p1;
238         ASSERT_EQ(2, p1.use_count());
239         p2.reset();
240         ASSERT_EQ(1, p1.use_count());
241         p1.reset();
242         ASSERT_EQ(0, p1.use_count());
243     }
244 
245     TEST_F(SharedPtrTest, unique) {
246         shared_ptr<A> p1(new A());
247         ASSERT_TRUE(p1.unique());
248         shared_ptr<A> p2;
249         ASSERT_FALSE(p2.unique());
250         p2 = p1;
251         ASSERT_FALSE(p1.unique());
252         ASSERT_FALSE(p2.unique());
253         p2.reset();
254         ASSERT_TRUE(p1.unique());
255         ASSERT_FALSE(p2.unique());
256         p1.reset();
257         ASSERT_FALSE(p1.unique());
258     }
259 
260     TEST_F(SharedPtrTest, bool) {
261         shared_ptr<A> p(new A());
262         ASSERT_TRUE((bool)p);
263         bool v = false;
264         if (p) {
265             v = true;
266         }
267     
268         ASSERT_TRUE(v);
269         p.reset();
270         ASSERT_FALSE((bool)p);
271     }
272 
273     TEST_F(SharedPtrTest, owner_before) {
274         A* a1 = new A(), *a2 = new A();
275         shared_ptr<A> p1(a1), p2(a2);
276         ASSERT_TRUE(p1.owner_before(p2) || p2.owner_before(p1));
277         ASSERT_FALSE(p1.owner_before(p2) && p2.owner_before(p1));
278         p2 = p1;
279         ASSERT_FALSE(p1.owner_before(p2));
280         ASSERT_FALSE(p2.owner_before(p1));
281     }
282 
283     TEST_F(SharedPtrTest, make_shared) {
284         shared_ptr<A> a = make_shared<A>(3);
285         a->Inc();
286         ASSERT_EQ(4, a->value_);
287         a = shared_ptr<A>(new A(8));
288         ASSERT_EQ(8, a->value_);
289         AssertCtorDtor("CCD");
290     }
291         
292     TEST_F(SharedPtrTest, swap_global) {
293         A* a1 = new A(), *a2 = new A2();
294         shared_ptr<A> p1(a1), p2(a2);
295         bool ownerBefore1 = p1.owner_before(p2);
296         swap(p1, p2);
297         ASSERT_EQ(a2, p1.get());
298         ASSERT_EQ(a1, p2.get());
299         bool ownerBefore2 = p1.owner_before(p2);
300         ASSERT_TRUE(ownerBefore1 || ownerBefore2);
301         ASSERT_FALSE(ownerBefore1 && ownerBefore2);
302     }
303 
304     TEST_F(SharedPtrTest, relation_op) {
305         A* a1 = new A();
306         A2* a2 = new A2();
307         shared_ptr<A> p1(a1);
308         shared_ptr<A2> p2(a2);
309         ASSERT_TRUE(p1 != p2);
310         ASSERT_FALSE(p1 == p2);
311         ASSERT_EQ(p1 < p2, a1 < a2);
312         ASSERT_EQ(p1 > p2, a1 > a2);
313         ASSERT_EQ(p1 <= p2, a1 <= a2);
314         ASSERT_EQ(p1 >= p2, a1 >= a2);
315 
316         p1 = p2;
317         ASSERT_TRUE(p1 == p2);
318         ASSERT_FALSE(p1 != p2);
319         ASSERT_FALSE(p1 < p2);
320         ASSERT_TRUE(p1 <= p2);
321         ASSERT_FALSE(p1 > p2);
322         ASSERT_TRUE(p1 >= p2);
323 
324     
325         ASSERT_FALSE(p1 == nullptr);
326         ASSERT_FALSE(nullptr == p1);
327         ASSERT_TRUE(p1 != nullptr);
328         ASSERT_TRUE(nullptr != p1);
329         ASSERT_FALSE(p1 < nullptr);
330         ASSERT_FALSE(p1 <= nullptr);
331         ASSERT_TRUE(nullptr < p1);
332         ASSERT_TRUE(nullptr <= p1);
333         ASSERT_TRUE(p1 > nullptr);
334         ASSERT_TRUE(p1 >= nullptr);
335         ASSERT_FALSE(nullptr > p1);
336         ASSERT_FALSE(nullptr >= p1);
337 
338         p2.reset();
339         ASSERT_TRUE(p2 == nullptr);
340         ASSERT_TRUE(nullptr == p2);
341         ASSERT_FALSE(p2 != nullptr);
342         ASSERT_FALSE(nullptr != p2);
343         ASSERT_FALSE(p2 < nullptr);
344         ASSERT_TRUE(p2 <= nullptr);
345         ASSERT_FALSE(nullptr < p2);
346         ASSERT_TRUE(nullptr <= p2);
347         ASSERT_FALSE(p2 > nullptr);
348         ASSERT_TRUE(p2 >= nullptr);
349         ASSERT_FALSE(nullptr > p2);
350         ASSERT_TRUE(nullptr >= p2);
351     }
352 }
